so that the oceans can provide us

As far back as we can go, we've seen

We know how to turn

First, we want to know where the fish are,

135.text:
It turns out the fish,
conveniently, are located

138.text:
for the most part, in our coastal areas
of the countries; in coastal zones.

143.text:
These are areas that national
jurisdictions have control over,

147.text:
and they can manage their fisheries
in these coastal areas.

151.text:
Coastal countries tend
to have jurisdictions

153.text: that go out about 200 nautical miles

155.text:
in areas that are called
exclusive economic zones;

159.text:
this is a good thing that they can control
their fisheries in these areas,

162.text:
because the high seas, which are
the darker areas on this map,

166.text: are a lot harder to control things,

168.text:
because it has to be done internationally,
you get into international agreements;

172.text:
and if any of you were checking
the climate change agreement,

175.text:
you know this can be a very slow,
frustrating, tedious process

178.text:
so controlling things nationally

182.text:
How many fish are actually
in these coastal areas

186.text:
You can see here about seven times
as many fish in the coastal areas

191.text: than there are in the high seas.

192.text:
So this a perfect place
for us to be focusing,

195.text: because we can actually get a lot done.

197.text:
We can restore a lot of our fisheries
if we focused in these coastal areas.

201.text:
But how many of these countries
do we have to work in?

204.text:
There is something
like 80 coastal countries.

206.text:
Do we have to fix fisheries management
in all of those countries?

210.text:
So we asked ourselves, "How many
countries do we need to focus on?",

213.text:
keeping in mind that the European Union
conveniently manages its fisheries

218.text: So, if we got good fisheries management

221.text:
in the European Union
and say nine other countries,

224.text:
how much of our fisheries
would we be covering?

226.text:
It turns out that the European Union
plus nine countries cover

230.text:
about two-thirds
of the world's fish catch.

233.text:
If we took it up to 24 countries
plus the European Union,

236.text:
we would be up to 90%;
almost all of the world's fish catch.

241.text:
So we think we can work
in a limited number of places

244.text: to make the fisheries come back,

246.text: but what do we have to do in these places?

248.text:
Based on our work in the US
and elsewhere, we know

251.text:
that there are three key things
we have to do to bring fisheries back.

255.text:
They are: we need to set quotas
or limits on how much we take;

259.text:
we need to reduce by-catch, which is
the accidental catching and killing a fish

264.text:
that we're not targeting
- and it's very wasteful -

267.text:
and three, we need to protect habitats,
the nursery areas, the spawning areas

272.text:
that these fish need to grow
and reproduce successfully,

274.text:
so that they can rebuild
their populations.

276.text:
If we can do those three things,
we know the fisheries will come back.

281.text:
We know because we've seen it happening
in a lot of different different places.

285.text:
This a slide that shows
the herring population in Norway

289.text:
that was crashing since the 1950s,
it was coming down.

292.text:
When Norway set limits
or quotas on its fishery,

298.text:
This is another example
- also happens to be from Norway -

307.text:
discards of these fish
they weren't targeting,

312.text:
When they set the discard limit,
the fishery came back.

316.text:
It's not just in Norway; we've seen this
happening in countries all over the world.

321.text:
Time and time again,
when these countries step in,

324.text:
and they put in sustainable fisheries
management policies,

327.text:
the fisheries, which are always crashing
it seems, are starting to come back.

332.text: So, there is a lot of promise here.

What does this mean

This means that we could increase, we take
that fishery catch that's on the decline,

340.text: and we could turn it upwards,

we could increase it up

349.text:
to not only bring the fish back
but to actually get more fish

that can feed more people
than we currently are now.

Right about now, we can feed
about 450 million people

361.text:
a fish meal a day based on

That number will go down

But if we put
fishery management practices

372.text:
like the ones I have described,

just because it's a good thing

If you look at how much fish protein

obviously, fish is

407.text:
something that's in short supply

It doesn't need any land.
It doesn't need a lot of fresh water.

It uses a lot less fresh water

so that you can grow the food

because we do have to get out

but agriculture can have
a carbon footprint in,

and fish has a much smaller one

It's already a big part of our diet,

which is a good thing
because we know that it's healthy for us.

It can reduce our risk of cancer,

Our ocean conservation

So, there's a constant push-pull there;

In the oceans, biodiversity

When we do things

And that's important

501.text:
Illegal fishing undermines the type
of sustainable fisheries management

505.text:
It can be when you catch fish
using gears that have been prohibited,

509.text:
when you fish in places
where you're not supposed to fish,

512.text:
you catch fish that are
the wrong size or the wrong species.

515.text:
Illegal fishing cheats the consumer,
and it also cheats honest fishermen.

519.text:
The way illegal fish get into our market
is through seafood fraud.

523.text: You might have heard about this.

524.text:
It's when fish are labeled
as something they're not.

527.text:
Think about the last time you had fish;
what were you eating?

530.text: Are you sure that's what it was?

531.text:
Because we tested
1,300 different fish samples,

533.text:
and about the third of them were not
what they were labeled to be.

537.text:
Snappers - nine out of ten
snappers were not snapper.

539.text: 59% of the tuna we tested was mislabeled.

543.text: And red snapper - we tested 120 samples,

546.text:
and only seven of them
were really red snapper,

548.text: so good luck finding a red snapper.

553.text: Seafood has a really complex supply chain,

555.text:
and in every step in this supply chain,
there's an opportunity for seafood fraud

563.text:
where the seafood industry can track
the seafood from the boat to the plate

567.text:
to make sure that the consumer can then
find out where their seafood came from.

571.text: This is a really important thing.

572.text:
It's being done by some
in the industry, but not enough

575.text:
so we're pushing a law in Congress
called The Safe Seafood Act.

578.text:
I am very excited today to announce
the release of a chef's petition

581.text:
where 450 chefs, including José Andrés,
have signed a petition

586.text:
calling on Congress
to support The Safe Seafood Act.

589.text: They've signed it because they believe

591.text:

Fishermen like it too,
so there's a good chance,

we can get the kind of support

610.text:
this the way we curb illegal fishing

613.text:
the quotas, habitat protection,

616.text: can do the jobs they can do.

We know that we can manage
